cs.man.ac.uk.stats

Interface I_ClassifierStatistics

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    ClassifierStatistics

    public interface I_ClassifierStatistics

    I_ClassifierStatistics provides an interface for providing the statistics needed to describe the accuracy of a classifier.

    The statistics are calculated using the true positive, true negative, false positive and false negative counts. These are defined as:

    True Positives (TP) = those input patterns correctly classified as positive. True Negatives (TN) = those input patterns correctly classified as negative. False Positives (FP) = those input patterns incorrectly classified as positive. False Negatives (FN) = those input patterns incorrectly classified as negative.

    Version:
    1.0, 05/02/13
    Author:
    Rob Lyon

    • Method Detail

      • getAccuracy

        double getAccuracy()
        Returns:
        the accuracy of the classifier. Accuracy is defined as: (TP + TN) / (TP + FP + FN + TN)

      • setAccuracy

        void setAccuracy(double accuracy)
        Sets the accuracy of the classifier. Accuracy is defined as: (TP + TN) / (TP + FP + FN + TN)
        Parameters:
        accuracy - how accurate the classifier is.

      • getPrecision

        double getPrecision()
        Returns:
        the precision of the classifier. Precision is defined as: (TP) / (TP+FP)

      • setPrecision

        void setPrecision(double precision)
        Sets the precision of the classifier. Precision is defined as: (TP) / (TP+FP)
        Parameters:
        precision - how precise the classifier is.

      • getRecall

        double getRecall()
        Returns:
        the recall (sensitivity) capabilities of the classifier. Recall is defined as: (TP) / (TP + FN)

      • setRecall

        void setRecall(double recall)
        Sets the recall (sensitivity) of the classifier. Recall is defined as: (TP) / (TP + FN)
        Parameters:
        recall - how well the classifier can recall positive instance.

      • getSpecificity

        double getSpecificity()
        Returns:
        the proportion of negative instances correctly classified. Defined as: (TN) / (FP+TN)

      • setSpecificity

        void setSpecificity(double specificity)
        Sets the specificity of the classifier. This is the proportion of negative instances correctly classified. Defined as: (TN) / (FP+TN)
        Parameters:
        specificity - the proportion of negative instances correctly classified.

      • getMatthewsCorrelation

        double getMatthewsCorrelation()
        Returns:
        the Matthews correlation coefficient.

      • setMatthewsCorrelation

        void setMatthewsCorrelation(double matthewsCorrelation)
        Returns the Matthews correlation coefficient. This is used in machine learning as a measure of the quality of binary (two-class) classifications. It takes into account true and false positives and negatives and is generally regarded as a balanced measure which can be used even if the classes are of very different sizes. The MCC is in essence a correlation coefficient between the observed and predicted binary classifications; it returns a value between -1 and +1. A coefficient of +1 represents a perfect prediction, 0 no better than random prediction and -1 indicates total disagreement between prediction and observation. The statistic is also known as the phi coefficient.
        Parameters:
        matthewsCorrelation - the Matthews correlation coefficient.

      • getfScore

        double getfScore()
        The F1 score (also F-score or F-measure) is a measure of a tests accuracy. It considers both the precision p and the recall r of the test to compute the score: p is the number of correct results divided by the number of all returned results and r is the number of correct results divided by the number of results that should have been returned.
        Returns:
        the F1 score

      • setFScore

        void setFScore(double fScore)
        Sets the F1 score (also F-score or F-measure) which is a measure of a tests accuracy.
        Parameters:
        fScore - the F1 score.

      • getNegativePredictiveValue

        double getNegativePredictiveValue()
        Gets the negative predictive value (NPV), which is a summary statistic defined as the proportion of input patterns identified as negative, that are correctly identified as such. A high NPV means that when the map yields a negative result, it is most likely correct in its assessment.
        Returns:
        the negative predictive value

      • setNegativePredictiveValue

        void setNegativePredictiveValue(double d)
        Sets the negative predictive value (NPV), which is a summary statistic defined as the proportion of input patterns identified as negative, that are correctly identified as such. A high NPV means that when the map yields a negative result, it is most likely correct in its assessment.
        Parameters:
        d - the negative predictive value

      • getKappa

        double getKappa()

        Gets the kappa statistic where,

        Kappa = (totalAccuracy - randomAccuracy) / (1 - randomAccuracy)

        where,

        totalAccuracy = (TP + TN) / (TP + TN + FP + FN)

        and

        randomAccuracy = (TN + FP) * (TN + FN) + (FN + TP) * (FP + TP) / (Total*Total).

        Returns:
        the kappa statistic.

      • getGMean

        double getGMean()
        Gets the G-mean statistic where, G-Mean = SQRT( ( TP /( TP + FN ) ) * ( TN / ( TN + FP ) ) )
        Returns:
        the G-Mean.

        double getTP()
        Returns:
        the number of true positives
